quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This episode is a unique glimpse into a startup and an approach to product that optimizes for moving quickly, thinking from first principles, and empowering individual team members.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a clear product-operating model (velocity + first principles + empowerment) that practitioners can emulate.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you're not familiar with Ramp, they're the fastest growing SaaS business in history, getting to over $100 million in annual run rate in two years, which is just wild.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark for what “velocity” can look like at extreme scale in a short time window.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And as you'll hear in this episode, they did this with 50 people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive data point suggesting outsized outcomes can come from very small teams with the right execution system.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: My advice is to seriously study how Ramp operates because there's a lot to learn from their success and their approach to product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Direct practitioner advice to treat Ramp’s operating model as a case study worth dissecting and adapting.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Half of all men will have cancer at some point in their lives, as will one-third of women.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A stark prevalence statistic that can motivate proactive screening and risk planning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to the American Cancer Society, early cancer detection has an 80% survival rate compared to less than 20% for late stage cancer.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Quantifies the impact of early detection, supporting an actionable bias toward earlier screening and checkups.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The Ezra team has helped 13% of their customers identify potential cancer early and 50% of them identify other clinically significant issues such as aneurysms, disc herniations, which may be is what I have, or fatty liver disease.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Provides concrete outcome rates and examples of non-cancer findings that can still be clinically important.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If your team's work is spread out across different documents and spreadsheets and a stack of workflow tools, that's why you need Coda.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for tool sprawl that suggests consolidating work into a single system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A simple operating model—centralize cross-format data—to reduce coordination friction and execution delays.

quotes.topic_title: What Ramp does and who it serves
quotes.text: Yeah, Ramp is a finance automation platform and corporate card solution for small and medium-sized businesses.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A crisp positioning statement that clarifies Ramp’s category and target customer segment (SMBs).

quotes.topic_title: What Ramp does and who it serves
quotes.text: So we help businesses essentially automate most things across expense management, card payments, bill payments, and accounting.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Defines the product scope as end-to-end finance workflow automation, useful for practitioners thinking in terms of integrated suites vs. point solutions.

quotes.topic_title: What Ramp does and who it serves
quotes.text: And we've helped 15,000 of such businesses automate a lot of their back office to focus on what truly matters, which is growing their company and providing value to their customers.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Combines a concrete adoption data point (15,000 businesses) with a clear value proposition: shifting time from back-office work to growth and customer value.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp’s growth stats and scale
quotes.text: I think we've hit a hundred million in annual revenue for the first two years and we've continued to grow significantly since then.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for what “historically fast” SaaS/FinTech growth can look like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp’s growth stats and scale
quotes.text: I think every day, about a thousand users join our platform.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A simple daily leading indicator teams can emulate to track growth momentum beyond revenue.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp’s growth stats and scale
quotes.text: And this year, we've grown and hit 600 million in savings, 8.5 million in hours saved for our customers by controlling spend and automating a lot of the manual tasks.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Shows how Ramp quantifies customer value in outcome metrics (savings + time), not just product usage.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp’s growth stats and scale
quotes.text: In two categories, the fastest Ramp to $200 million in run rate.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable positioning statement that frames growth as a category-defining speed milestone.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp’s growth stats and scale
quotes.text: there's this one word that immediately comes to mind when people think of how Ramp operates and that word is velocity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces “velocity” as an operating principle/framework for how the company executes day to day.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity as Ramp’s core operating principle
quotes.text: Velocity is everything at Ramp. It's how we design our product development process. It's how we incentivize teams, it's who we want to hire, it's who we want to promote, and it's everything around how we make decisions and how we organize the organization.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A clear operating-system-level framework for making velocity the organizing principle across process, incentives, talent, and org design.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity as Ramp’s core operating principle
quotes.text: it wasn't so much which path we wanted to pick, but rather how fast we were able to execute on that path.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization: execution speed can matter more than perfect strategy selection when opportunity is large.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity as Ramp’s core operating principle
quotes.text: realistically, teams that have high velocity are able to actually get to that impact over time by iterating.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical mental model that reframes velocity as a compounding mechanism for impact through iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity as Ramp’s core operating principle
quotes.text: It's also a great way to have positive selection in terms of talent because talent wants to join companies that ship fast.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Actionable hiring insight: shipping velocity itself can be a talent magnet and selection mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity as Ramp’s core operating principle
quotes.text: And it's also a great way just de-risk decisions and decision making. If the cost of that decision is really low, then you're able to essentially simplify a lot of decisions.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A methodology for decision-making: lower the cost of decisions via fast iteration to simplify and de-risk choices.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of extreme shipping speed
quotes.text: Yeah. So when I joined, we were about 10-ish folks, about eight engineers, and in three months, we built a competitor to Amex.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Concrete benchmark showing how a very small team can ship a major product in an extremely compressed timeline.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of extreme shipping speed
quotes.text: We basically gave a team goal of building a competitor, Bill.com. It was three engineers, one designer, one PM three months, and they hit out of the park.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Specific resourcing + timebox example practitioners can use to calibrate team size and deadlines for big bets.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of extreme shipping speed
quotes.text: And I think the recipe for all this is constantly small teams have a single-threaded focus, give them the resources they need to execute big lofty goals, very tight timelines, and then shield them from the chaos that is the rest of the organization.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A clear, reusable operating model for driving extreme shipping speed with small teams.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples of extreme shipping speed
quotes.text: So basically don't bother them and don't even tell the rest of the company that you're doing these things until they find product market fit, until they actually find that early traction and then they can bring in more resources.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance on reducing internal visibility to protect focus until traction is proven.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded teams and focus mechanics
quotes.text: And so what I mean by single threaded is there's only one goal, one thread, that they're waking up in the morning to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Defines the core mental model of “single-threaded” work as a strict one-goal focus.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded teams and focus mechanics
quotes.text: And in order to remove that, you basically need to remove anything else that they're being asked to do to just focus on that thing, whether it's any type of research or any type of production engineering or any type of process that's outside of that single goal.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Gives an actionable prescription: remove all non-goal responsibilities (including “important” adjacent work) to preserve speed.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded teams and focus mechanics
quotes.text: So, for example, we launched a flex product over the last summer, that was a single-threaded team just focused on eCommerce companies and their needs with more cash flow conversion and cash flow smoothing.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Concrete example of a single-threaded team applied to a specific product and customer segment.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded teams and focus mechanics
quotes.text: So we have layers of protective tissue to core teams, but I would say for any of these big bets, you basically have to pull folks from different teams and reorganize a sub-team.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Introduces a structural approach—“protective tissue” plus forming dedicated sub-teams—to shield focus from interruptions.

quotes.topic_title: Single-threaded teams and focus mechanics
quotes.text: I think it gets more challenging when you go from one to two rather than zero to one.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that scaling from one to two products/threads can be harder than starting from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Lofty goals anchored by markets and design
quotes.text: So the first thing is we have market comparables, which is very exciting for us.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical way to keep “lofty goals” grounded is to anchor ambition in real, proven reference points from adjacent companies/markets.

quotes.topic_title: Lofty goals anchored by markets and design
quotes.text: So when you look at Bill.com, they're a publicly traded company, Expensify, publicly traded, or Concur or Coupa, these are all large players that are actually very motivating and largely de-risk some of the business decisions you're making.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Using established incumbents as comparables can both motivate teams and reduce perceived risk in strategic bets.

quotes.topic_title: Lofty goals anchored by markets and design
quotes.text: We also use designs as a way to motivate teams.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Design isn’t just execution—it’s used as a motivational tool to align and energize teams around a tangible future.

quotes.topic_title: Lofty goals anchored by markets and design
quotes.text: So we constantly go back to these cornerstone, Loom walkthroughs of Figma prototypes that the design spend a lot of time talking through and I think that's a big part of the motivation.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A repeatable operating mechanism: use “cornerstone” prototype walkthroughs to keep teams aligned on the target experience.

quotes.topic_title: Lofty goals anchored by markets and design
quotes.text: But you're able to move super, super fast if you have those two things in mind, the market and the revenue goal, because very revenue driven as a company and the designs that can really keep you anchored on what this could look like.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A speed framework: combine clear market/revenue targets with concrete design prototypes to maintain focus and accelerate execution.

quotes.topic_title: Context over control: empowering product teams
quotes.text: And so that's where you really just start alignment is, what is the goal that you're going after? What is the hypothesis that you have to reach that goal? What is the data by which you're coming up with that hypothesis? And then what is the potential solution to test that hypothesis?
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical alignment framework that keeps leaders and teams focused on goals, hypotheses, and data before debating solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Context over control: empowering product teams
quotes.text: And oftentimes, more junior leaders, and I was certainly in that camp earlier on, kept focusing on the solutions and debating the right solution when in fact you should really be debating upstream of that. You should be debating the interpretation of data, you should be debating the hypotheses and the different ideas that you have there as to what's really going on or you should be debating the goals themselves.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that the highest-leverage debates are about goals, hypotheses, and data—not solution details.

quotes.topic_title: Context over control: empowering product teams
quotes.text: And so whenever things went wrong at Ramp, it was when I was being prescriptive with regards to the solution without actually explaining and aligning upstream on the goal, the hypothesis, and the data.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A clear failure mode that practitioners can watch for: prescribing solutions without shared upstream context breaks empowerment.

quotes.topic_title: Context over control: empowering product teams
quotes.text: I think that the contract between me and the team is really their strategy and their roadmap. And as long as we are aligned on the strategy, and we can get into that, and aligned on the roadmap and the timing, that's their contract.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for delegation: align on strategy/roadmap as the “contract,” then let teams execute.

quotes.topic_title: Context over control: empowering product teams
quotes.text: So I basically have teams ... All my directs post their goals every week first thing Monday. The goal there is to also have them review each other's goals.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete operational practice for empowerment and alignment: weekly goal publishing plus peer review.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling product quality while moving fast
quotes.text: I think we're relating now is any large rock that we have on the roadmap needs to be brought into the product review process, where myself and the head of design are present and giving feedback, but it needs to be structured in a way where you are asking specifically for what type of feedback you need and you're highlighting the key risks and tradeoffs that you're making implicitly in that review.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A lightweight review gate for big bets that scales by forcing teams to explicitly request feedback and surface risks/tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling product quality while moving fast
quotes.text: When we make the decision to go live to the rest of the customer base and asking sales to start selling, that's where I'll really come in and stress test the hypotheses and the decisions. It's further downstream so it's more risky, but because we move so fast, you don't waste that much time if you have to pull it back.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical model for concentrating senior scrutiny at the GA moment, relying on speed to reduce the cost of reversals.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling product quality while moving fast
quotes.text: And so we've really focused on what are the control mechanisms that ensure that your high velocity doesn't tank the business.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Frames velocity as safe only when paired with explicit control mechanisms, not as an unconditional good.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling product quality while moving fast
quotes.text: We report back operational overhead, meaning the percentage of tickets that come from your product area normalized by the number of users that are using that product. And that's a core contract that the team has to maintain a low or lower part of operational burden.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete, measurable quality bar (ticket rate per user) that teams are accountable for as a “contract.”

quotes.topic_title: Scaling product quality while moving fast
quotes.text: As long as you maintain those metrics, you can do whatever you want. But the moment that these things are under the red, you can't ship new features and you need to revert back to the [inaudible 00:24:03].
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A clear enforcement mechanism: quality/ops metrics act as release gates that halt feature shipping when they degrade.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for teams pressured to “move faster”
quotes.text: You can't ask for velocity and not have empowerment and not trust and not eliminate process and not increase the focus.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A clear prerequisite checklist that reframes “move faster” as an organizational design problem, not a PM effort problem.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for teams pressured to “move faster”
quotes.text: The second thing that I would say is the biggest waste of time is meetings and status updates.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable diagnosis of where velocity is commonly lost, pointing teams to cut calendar overhead first.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for teams pressured to “move faster”
quotes.text: I've never had a status meeting. I've never scheduled a status meeting. Statuses are done async.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete operating practice teams can copy to reduce coordination costs while keeping accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for teams pressured to “move faster”
quotes.text: So here's what we're doing and here's what we're not doing and why and which one would you pick? Give them a menu of items.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical decision-making method for forcing focus and making tradeoffs explicit with leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for teams pressured to “move faster”
quotes.text: What that means is the CEO has less say in the product that is built and the engineers have a lot more say into it.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A counterintuitive definition of empowerment that ties velocity to shifting decision rights closer to builders.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout, motivation, and sustainable intensity
quotes.text: I think the debate around working hard and burnout misses a key point, which is all about how much impact and how good you feel about the work that you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Reframes burnout away from hours worked toward perceived impact and emotional reward, which leaders can influence through goal-setting and scope.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout, motivation, and sustainable intensity
quotes.text: And I think that for me, when I felt burnout, it was actually at the time where I had the lowest amount of velocity.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Counterintuitive claim that slow progress—not high intensity—can be the bigger burnout driver, implying teams should remove blockers to increase momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout, motivation, and sustainable intensity
quotes.text: And so I actually think velocity is a way to potentially avoid burnout.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model: increasing shipping cadence and momentum can be protective against burnout when paired with focus.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout, motivation, and sustainable intensity
quotes.text: And I think that that's the role of management is to make everyone on your team feel like it's their goal.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Actionable management principle: create ownership by ensuring goals feel personally meaningful to each team member, not just top-down directives.

quotes.topic_title: Burnout, motivation, and sustainable intensity
quotes.text: If everyone feels like it's their team, it's their company, their mini company, then they will radically avoid burnout.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Provides an ownership-based framework for burnout prevention: structure teams so individuals feel empowered and accountable like running a “mini company.”

quotes.topic_title: Planning vs doing: where accuracy matters
quotes.text: I think there's certain things that we plan for. And so the question really is because accuracy has cost, make sure that you're only increasing the accuracy of planning for the things that have high value of that accuracy.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for where to invest planning effort: treat accuracy as costly and spend it only where it pays off.

quotes.topic_title: Planning vs doing: where accuracy matters
quotes.text: And so those things for us are large market moments where we have products, marketing, and sales all coordinating these big moments.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete example of the “plan when coordination value is high” principle—major cross-functional launches.

quotes.topic_title: Planning vs doing: where accuracy matters
quotes.text: But be very accurate on the things that truly, truly matter. The rest actually doesn't matter.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A crisp prioritization heuristic: reserve rigor for the few critical bets and let everything else stay flexible.

quotes.topic_title: Planning vs doing: where accuracy matters
quotes.text: You don't need a lot of accuracy and confidence on when specifically certain features will be live. It's much better to spend whatever time you would spend trying to create accuracy and creating velocity.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Counterintuitive execution advice: stop over-forecasting feature timelines and redirect that effort into shipping faster.

quotes.topic_title: Planning vs doing: where accuracy matters
quotes.text: Again, the goals and the value and the problem and the vision, that's consistent. The specifics, the timing, the quarterly scopes, all these things, yes, it changes, but what you want to avoid is the thrash of people waking up and feeling like they're working at a different company or that leaders are constantly changing their minds.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A stability model for high-velocity orgs: keep strategy constant while allowing tactics and timelines to shift without causing organizational whiplash.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It allows you to quickly build a CRM that matches your unique workflows and data structures.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Highlights a practical principle: tailor systems to your actual workflows/data instead of forcing your team into a rigid tool.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Within minutes of connecting your email and calendar, you'll have a CRM that's already set up complete with customer profiles and automatic data enrichment.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of reducing setup time and manual work via automation and pre-populated data.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: No more slow deployments, outdated user experiences or tedious manual data input.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Memorable checklist of common operational bottlenecks to eliminate when choosing/building internal tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Attio, you can build and adapt your CRM on the fly no matter your business model or company stage.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Emphasizes an adaptable operating model—optimize for continuous iteration rather than one-time “implementation.”

quotes.topic_title: Strategy as a contract: goals to initiatives
quotes.text: Strategy means a lot of different things. In my mind, strategy is about how do we get to our goals? And it's not a roadmap and it's not a vision, it's something right in between that.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Defines a clear mental model for strategy as the bridge between vision and execution, avoiding common confusion with roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy as a contract: goals to initiatives
quotes.text: So the first thing you need to do is align on what are the goals, what do you want to see in the world? Then the hypothesis, why do you think this will work? Figure out why we're uniquely positioned as a company to get after that goal. Figure out the metrics by which you would measure whether we reach that goal and then talk about the initiatives, talk about the risks, and talk about the long-term outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Lays out a practical “strategy doc” checklist that teams can use as a repeatable contract from goals to outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy as a contract: goals to initiatives
quotes.text: And now every pod basically spends time writing that doc for themselves.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Shows an empowerment mechanism: teams own their strategy narrative rather than receiving it top-down.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy as a contract: goals to initiatives
quotes.text: And it became very political, very annoying. And largely, our entire R&D team was like, "Look, we're just going to execute on the roadmap, screw the OKRs."
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A contrarian cautionary tale about how OKR processes can backfire into politics and disengagement if over-optimized.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy as a contract: goals to initiatives
quotes.text: And so we moved from quarterly, very expensive quarterly planning, which took one month every three months, so basically 33% of the time was planning, to a biannual one-pager on, these are the company priorities and it's much more smooth and much faster.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Provides a concrete process change with a striking planning-cost data point and a simpler alternative practitioners can copy.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs skepticism and roadmap as the contract
quotes.text: One of the biggest values, I think, of software is how do you reuse the components that you've built to increase, again, velocity and impact.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A reusable-components mental model for choosing product bets that compound speed and leverage existing capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs skepticism and roadmap as the contract
quotes.text: So we believed that we were uniquely positioned to get after that space because we already had money movement. We already had some type of liability. We already integrated with accounting systems and we had a pretty strong risk process that can govern all that. And the employees that were requesting to pay these bills were already on the platform.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete “right to win” checklist (capabilities, integrations, risk, distribution) applied to expanding from cards into bill pay.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs skepticism and roadmap as the contract
quotes.text: I largely stay away from OKRs from a product perspective.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that challenges the default assumption that product teams should run on OKRs.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs skepticism and roadmap as the contract
quotes.text: But, again, an OKR is just a method to measure an objective with metrics and you can use them at various levels of granularity. I stay away from them from a product perspective because, again, I want to focus on velocity, which is just output, which is your roadmap, but they're pretty strong at more of the cross-functional side of things as well as the financial side of things.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A practical boundary: use OKRs for cross-functional/financial alignment, but keep product execution centered on roadmap-driven output and velocity.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs skepticism and roadmap as the contract
quotes.text: And at the end of the day, again, the contract is your product roadmap and that's the contract you have, the sales organization. Marketing can take that product roadmap and create market moments.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A clear operating model: treat the roadmap as the primary commitment that downstream teams (Sales/Marketing) can reliably plan around.

quotes.topic_title: First principles thinking and a support example
quotes.text: And so it's really important when you're dealing with something that hasn't been done before to think from first principles. And what I mean by that is you don't pattern match from your past experience, but you go back to the fundamentals of what we're trying to do and you think through them very, very deeply.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Defines first-principles thinking as avoiding pattern-matching and instead reasoning from fundamentals—especially critical in novel, complex businesses.

quotes.topic_title: First principles thinking and a support example
quotes.text: And that means you need to hire people who can think from first principles and be okay putting aside their experience.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Turns first-principles thinking into a hiring bar: prioritize candidates who can suspend prior playbooks when context demands it.

quotes.topic_title: First principles thinking and a support example
quotes.text: And how also you can't influence teams by saying, "I've seen this before." That's just like an anti-pattern. You can't say, "My past company, X, Y, Z."
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A contrarian cultural norm: relying on “at my last company” credibility can backfire and block real problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: First principles thinking and a support example
quotes.text: So support reports into me. And the first principle there was saying, "Well, every support ticket is a failure of our product."
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: A concrete org-design example: treat support demand as product defects and structurally align support under product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: First principles thinking and a support example
quotes.text: And so instead of hiring people who were focused just on resolving the ticket, we incentivized people to actually decrease number of tickets over time and decrease deflection or increase deflection.
quotes.speaker: Geoff Charles
quotes.context: Operationalizes the philosophy with incentives: optimize support for reducing future tickets (and improving deflection), not just closing cases.
